results.title: A Soho story
results.brief_description: Mac, the busker, who entertained London theatre queues for twenty years, his life and opinions. The narrator’s search for Mac throughout Soho, their meeting, Mac’s reminiscences - his break with his middle-class upbringing, his early days in Soho, a job as a club doorman, his meeting with his wife and their return to busking together, the breakdown of their marriage and his present life as an artist.

results.title: A Smoked husband
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith and American Mutoscope and Biograph Company
results.brief_description: A husband’s groundless jealousy leads to farcical misadventures. Cast includes John R. Cumpson, Florence Lawrence, Linda Arvidson, George Gebhardt, Mack Sennett. Silent film with no intertitles.

results.title: A Smattering of spots
results.brief_description: Why some people enjoy television commercials. Imaginative use of the art of animated drawings and musical scoring make these fourteen “spots” immensely amusing. Includes five award winners. Written, designed and scored by A. Babbit, De. Elliott, T. Farlow, S. Freburg, A. Gillespie, R. Guidi, B. Hawinks, J. Hubley, W. Littlejohn, D. Ellington.

results.title: A Skeleton in the crop: the story of skeleton weed (chondrilla juncea) in Australia
results.creator_credit: David Corke, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Ever since Skeleton Weed was first discovered in Australia in the early 1900’s, farmers and scientists have been searching for a way to stop it spreading through the wheatlands of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. This is the story of their search. Using archival footage and stills, it tells of the early frustrations over failure to eradicate the weed, the hostility of wheat farmers faced with a problem they did not understand, and their growing appreciation of the role of scientific research in devising the best methods of keeping Skeleton Weed in check.
results.title_for_label: A Skeleton in the crop: the story of skeleton weed (chondrilla juncea) in Australia

results.title: A Sign Is a fine investment
results.creator_credit: Judith Williamson and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: From the 1890s until the 1930s, early advertising frequently used images of industrial work to sell its products. Modern advertising, on the other hand, surrounds us with images of idealised homes and families, shopping and holidays, offering a world of consumerism in which work has become invisible. This film investigates the disappearance of work from advertising

results.title: A Shopping expedition (K)
results.creator_credit: Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description: Adapted from chapter 4 from the book “A Bear called Paddington” written by Michael Bond. Judy and Mrs Brown take Paddington to fashionable Barkridges’ department store to buy a pair of pyjamas. Although the store is having a big sale, Pyjama Week has been a disaster. After finding a pair of colourful pyjamas, Paddington enters what he believes to be a dressing room but which actually turns out to be the shop window. Fortunately his antics in the window make Pyjama Week a success and the grateful store manager makes Paddington a gift of anything he would like from the store. Narrated by Michael Hordern. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: A Shocking affair
results.brief_description: An animated illustration of the safety rule: “Never touch plumbing and electrical fixtures at the same time.” In the film we see a young woman commit the fatal error of switching on an electric light while in her bath. After a fleeting glimpse of a gravestone with the inscription R.I.P., we see her in the next world where in her celestial tub she is about to repeat her mistake but remembers the consequences just in time.

results.title: A Ship is born
results.brief_description: Offers an impressionistic view of shipbuilding and the baptismal launching of a ship, showing the relationship between man and his work. Shows the gaiety of the launching day contrasted with the tension of the workers, whose last job is to knock out the timber stills and send the ship down to the water.
